title: Why is there only 1 AD Support Champion?
body:
I'm glad we've Yuumi, love the new champion, honest.

But, I find that every role has many options for AD champions except for support. Support only has Pyke. Why is that?

The real answer to your question lies in the fact that almost nearly every AD champion _that could support_ is melee and they do not have the required base damages or stats in order to be useful with a low income.

There are a lot of champions who theoretically could be AD supports, but they are not viable due to the meta of the game itself. The most commonly played champions bottom are squishy ranged AD scaling carries who generally turn into dangerous threats when fed. Knowing this, there are two different styles used to go with them: 

1. Champions who can 'protect' the carry and 
2. Aggressive champions who can help snowball the carry

Most real supports are given high base damages and numbers on their abilities to compensate for the lack of gold income which they will have. This is paired usually with low scalings to prevent them from being abused in other lanes. In the case of most AD champions, they're designed the complete opposite with low base damages but moderate to very high scalings.

As for why Riot doesn't make AD scaling supports, AD is cheaper and more effective than both Tank items and Ability Power items currently. This is also not to mention that all auto attacks use Attack Damage. Even if Riot makes a "balanced" AD support champion that champion will always be better in a solo lane. 

When you think about what I said above, basically the champion would need really high base damages (think about Pyke's ultimate) in order to be successful as a Support. Players are always going to take advantage of this in a solo lane since other champions are not designed with the same high base damages. If Riot makes the champion have both low scaling and low base damages, they will be useless and never picked, so there wouldn't be any point in making the champion in the first place.

Anyway, I think it could work thematically but it would fall apart in game. There's plenty of inspiration for abilities:

P: Allies in a cone behind you take (think MF Q) x% less damage, scaling with ranks in R up to x%

Q: Low CD Shield Bash, auto attack reset, each time it's used it applies stacking armour shred up to 15%

W: Rally or war cry skill, give your allies move speed/shield/whatever

E: Long range dash with a mini-stun at the end (range like Thresh Q lol), if it connects with an enemy grants a shield/damage reduction/move speed/whatever

R: Redirect x% damage to allies unto yourself, up to x% additionally gain a shield for each ally nearby, 100 per ally increased by hp/armour/whatever. At the end of the effect, gain move speed based on how much damage you've mitigated 10% per 300 damage mitigated or something. 

There, we have a crusader or champion or whatever you'd prefer to call it. A kit made in 10 seconds that could, with lots of tweaks, be that of a support champs. Scale all of his damage off AD and scale his utility off a combination of AD and HP _or_ armour. Cool. He would still build full tank, regardless of having AD scalings, maybe a Steraks or Cleaver for the HP shield and additional armour shred. 

The problem with AD supports is that they can go 2 ways only - the Pyke route of being an assassin, in which case they needed to be heavily gated by CD's or mana costs etc etc or else they become too unbalanced against traditional bot lanes. The other route is Leona/Braum/Taric types who have a great kit of engaging and staying in the fight but don't care about damage, they just want to survive. They all have kits that synergize with their autos and spells that empower said autos but none of them build AD items, except trashcans building IBG and Titanic. 

Any AD supp would be an assassin or a champ who, while they might scale off AD, don't care because their kit is designed to support others and a Duskblade just doesn't fit that bill.

 As for autos, reliability pretty much depends on range, gapclosing, and tank stats. Putting aside range for the moment, the ability to close is pretty standard at this point. That leaves tank stats. Which brings us back to hitting numbers, which will probably get balanced around a tradeoff between damage scaling and tankiness. Which... sounds a lot like Pyke, in retrospect.
